page.title: 03WIGMORE CHURCH
page.content: WIGMORE CHURCH There was probably a church in Wigmore as early as Saxon times, but the present church dedicated to St. James dates from Norman times. The 14th Century chancel is narrower than the oringinal Norman one. It was restored in 1868 at a cost of Â£270 and the stained glass in the North and South windows probably date from that time. The Nave was restored in 1864. The pews date from that year. In 1978 when the walls were stripped fro replastering, a herring bone structuring was revealed. It is likely that the 11th Century building was entirely of this structure. The South Aisle was added in the 14th Century as were the North Chapel, the 61 foot tower and the Porch.
